title: About
text:
I have a PhD in Neuroscience from the University of Oregon and work as a Workflow Coach for Posit Software.
I tend to find the social lives of non-human animals interesting - thus crows and whales as subject matter.

title: Stars & Mountains Mug
text: Inspired by looking at a picture of this stars cup, I made this!

title: Crow Babies
text:
Available for Purchase Price: $45
Email may.lisa2@gmail.com to inquire.

This summer I watched a juvenile crow beg for food while she was standing on food. The begging went on for days. Man, oh man, it really made me empathize with the parents. And crows do it every year! This a set of four small plates is an ode to parental patience and how hard it is to raise kids. :) They’re little plates - perfect for dunking chicken nuggets in ketchup or holding your rings.

title: Singing Whale
text: Sigh. I really loved this whale, but I screwed up the glazing. So we’ll just say that I learned a lot. Maybe someday I’ll try to reglaze and fire.

title: Mark Making Mug
text:
I got up in the middle of the night with this strong urge to carve. Not really about a final image, but a feeling of what my hands wanted to do. So I got up and carved this. In art school people talked about “being interested in mark making*” and I always thought that was pretentious. But there’s something soothing about making the same motion over and over - repetitive hand movements. Why knitting, coloring, all kinds of things are soothing. I find working with clay therapeutic, and it was soothing to do this just focused on the feeling, not with an image of how I wanted it to turn out.
Glaze notes: So far it’s saffron yellow and flame Speedball underglaze. After bisque, I want to fill in the carving spots with black or brown underglaze, then glaze the whole thing maybe with saffron glaze?
*Note: the only other time I heard this was daycare teachers talking about babies making art - just being interested in what it’s like to make a mark.

title: Sketchy Crows
text:
Okay, so this is important to me because it’s more fluid, more like a sketch, more kinda seeing what happens. Less like a plan with very clear clean outlines, less like a cartoon, less controlled. I like stuff that has a weird messy energy.
Carving clay feels amazing. Sometimes I crave it (not making that up). I loved the chaos of carving those horizontal stripes. Chaos gremlin release!
This crow from behind is my favorite. Mysterious. 
Then she turns and make awkward eye contact. Whut? 
This is the least successful carving although the one I love the most from the reference sketch. I can’t get that head tilt right yet! 
This is the reference sketch I made to work from. 
And here’s an example of the reference pictures I’m taking of MY CROWS lately because they trust me and come when I whistle and come very close to me. Squeeeeeeeeeeee.

title: Mason Stain Mugs
text:
Aaauuuugh how can I explain how interested I am in the rows of tiny envelopes of color at clay supply stores??
I want colored clay. I don’t want to make it marbled. I don’t want to do anything fancy with it. I just want really brightly colored clay and no glaze.
I mean…look at these clay colors. Gasp. 
Obviously I can create beautiful colors with glaze. Why does this seem better? B/c it’s not just putting a layer on it, it’s like…coloring the essence of it.
Anyways, I’m trying it! I bought two tiny envelopes, mostly choosing b/c these were two that were I think that were the least expensive. 
I’ve been reading a lot about it. I’m going to wedge each of these into a 1.25 to 1.5 lb of clay and see what happens.
Supposedly the celadon has cobalt in it so it’s more likely to be bright.
Oh yeah, and both of these are toxic heavy metals. So I see why everyone doesn’t do this.

title: Holy Whale
text:
Okay, okay, okay - this is glazed and ready for the final fire. 
This is a big deal b/c:
- first sculpture cutting it open and in pieces to hollow out
- first time actually taking the time to run test tiles to plan the glaze instead of just hoping for the best.

Laguna sculpture clay Glaze notes: 
So many times, the battle isn’t knowing the right thing to do but finding the patience and give a shit to actually do it the way that’ll turn out cool.
It’s like I need a solid 2 years of “no, I’m not doing that. You can’t make me.” And then I finally surrender to needing to be patient and work hard at something, at which point I do a deep dive and then I’m good at it.
